docs.title: Blender Math Anim Add-on
docs.text:
Welcome to the documentation for Blender Math Anim, an advanced add-on for visualizing and animating math functions, rendering formulas, and drawing directly inside Blender.

This site contains:

  • Installation guide
  • Usage tutorials
    • Function plotting and animation workflows
    • Formula generation and animation workflows
    • Free Drawings
    • Morphing setups
  • API reference
  • Advanced Topics

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text:
• Use numexpr for fast expression evaluation
  • Optimize sample count for better live animation
  • Avoid super heavy curves
  • Try to keep expression complexity low

docs.title: Expression Engine (numexpr)
docs.text: The add-on uses numexpr instead of Python eval:

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Faster evaluation
  • Prevents arbitrary code execution
  • Vectorized math
  • Safe execution sandbox

docs.title: Supported features
docs.text:
• All NumPy-compatible functions
  • Elementwise operations
  • Logical and comparison operators

docs.title: Live Update System
docs.text:
Live update regenerates the curve automatically when:

  • parameter value changes
  • domain or sample count changes

docs.title: 1. Requirements
docs.text:
• Blender version 4.4 or 5.0
    • Blender 4.5 doesn't work due to its internal bugs
  • Supports macOS, Windows, Linux
  • It will requires optex for rendering formulas (optional)
    • Make sure optex command is available in your system PATH
    • If you can run optex from a terminal, you're good to go.

docs.title: 2. Installing the Add-on
docs.text:
1. Open Blender → Edit → Preferences → Get-Extentions
  2. Choose Install from Diks...
  3. Select the ZIP file and click the Install from Disk button
  4. By default, it should be enabled, double check to make sure it's enabled, if not, just enable it

docs.title: 3. Setting Up the Add-on
docs.text:
Click Add-ons then search Math Anim, expand it.

  1. The fonts path libraries are necessary unless you don't use the formula part
    • Only .ttf and .otf fonts are supported, if your PDF files are compiled with other font types, like latex with .pfb fonts (they are so outdated), it will use Blender default font instead.
    • All the needed python packages are bundled with the add-on except the OpTex which doesn't have a python package.
    • OpTeX is just an latex engine (like lualatex, xelatex), it only supports modern .ttf and .otf fonts, it's optianl.
    • You can use Typst which is also an modern typesetting engine by only supporting .ttf and .otf fonts and the Typst is bundled with this add-on.
    • If you installed OpTex, make sure it's in your system PATH:
      • It is in the PATH if you can run optex from a terminal, for Windows, MacOS, and Linux.
      • For both Typst and OpTex, check their documentations for their free available fonts to use.
  2. You can also preset formulas for both Typst and OpTex for reference or speed up your workflow. Once they're set, they will be showed up in the add-on panel under formula section, otherwise, they will not show up.
  3. The Extra Vars are extra reserved variables for function plotting besides x,y,z,u,v,t etc, so if you set the number to 10, you will have x0, x1, ..., x9 as extra variables to use, similarly for y,z,u,v,t etc.
  4. You can also change the add-on N panel location, but it is recommended to keep it under the default Tool location.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Blender Math Anim is a Blender add-on designed for math visualization, plotting, animation, and drawing inside Blender.

docs.title: ✨ Features
docs.text:
• Generate and animate mathematical functions:
  • explicit functions
  • parametric curves
  • polar functions
  • ODE functions
  • implicit functions
  • Multiple animation options:
  • writing animation
  • parameter driving
  • morphing between plottings, text, drawings
  • Formula generating using Typst / OpTeX / PDF
  • Freehand drawings
  • Real-time updates with safe math engine (numexpr)
  • Sliders for any detected parameters

docs.title: Use cases
docs.text:
• Classroom math demonstrations
  • Data visualization
  • TikTok/YouTube math animation
  • Scientific animations
  • Educational content

docs.title: Usage Overview
docs.text: This section covers the core workflow of the add-on.

docs.title: Main components:
docs.text:
• Function Plotting
  • Formula Generating
  • Free Drawing
  • Morphing System

Each tool appears in the Math Anim tab in the 3D View.

docs.title: Free Drawing
docs.text:
1. Add/Select drawing holding object and layers → Drawing
  2. Use mouse or tablet to draw or write stuffs.
  3. Supports:
  4. All native grease pencil tools and settings
  5. Can also manually adjust some controls
  6. Grease pencil effect modifiers

docs.title: Writing Animation
docs.text:
• Preset animations can easily apply to Drawing layers.
  • Morph between and across drawings and other types

docs.title: Creating a Function Plot
docs.text:
1. Select Function type
  2. Enter a mathematical expression, e.g.: sin(2pit)
  3. Set domain and resolution:
  4. *_min, *_max and *_resolution
  5. Set parameter values
  6. Add new or update plottings
  7. Adjust settings
  8. Live update variables and parameters

docs.title: Supported Expressions
docs.text:
• Common expressions, like sin, cos, tan, exp, log, sqrt, abs
  • Common math operators, like +, -, *, /, ^

docs.title: Parameter Sliders
docs.text:
The add-on auto-detects parameters:

Example: sin(a * t + phi) → creates sliders for a, phi.
